awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award:   Long Term Interactions Between Social Organization And Land Use Practices
awd_abstract_narration:
Doctoral dissertation student Erin McDonald, under the supervision of co-PI Dr. Timothy Chevral, will identify shifts in subsistence practices and examine the relationship between subsistence and socio-political organization from the Late Bronze Age to the Early Medieval Period in Ireland. In recent years, archaeologists world-wide have re-opened the debate on how past societies were organized, questioning the validity of assuming that all prehistoric rulers had robust top-down powers within highly hierarchic societies. McDonald, using prehistoric and early historic Ireland as a case study, will assess these relationships through analysis of pollen from bogs near archaeological sites from relevant periods: the Late Bronze Age (11th to 9th centuries BCE), Iron Age (9th cent. BCE to 5th cent. CE), and Early Medieval Period (post 5th cent. CE). In many regions of the developing world today centralized political power is limited and social order is maintained through negotiation across a hierarchical power structure. This research has the potential to provide insight into how such a process functioned across time.

In comparison with earlier and later periods, the Iron Age saw unusual peaks in ritual activity at elite civic-ceremonial sites, and increased evidence for metal production, acquisition and trade, all suggesting major socio-political reorganization. The complex politics of the Iron Age are the focus of many Early Medieval Irish sagas, yet the reality of the Iron Age is poorly understood due to a lack of archaeological sites other than political and ceremonial hubs. The number of known Iron Age settlements expanded during the late 20th century Irish economic boom, yet little is understood about how the society worked. 

Were peaks and lulls in activity at political centers paralleled by increases in workload and effort in farming and herding communities? If so, farmers might have been called to produce more for tribute or taxes to support an elite. If not, the reach of government was less than is often assumed. If there are parallels, the directionality and timing of change is important. It is commonly assumed that rulers command increased production, but it can also be the case that pre-existing productivity among farmers enables the rise of elites.

To compensate for gaps in archaeological knowledge, these research questions are approached through analysis of ancient pollen, drawn from stratified, datable cores close to archaeological sites. Pollen grains, resistant to decay, continuously accumulate in the Irish Midlands peat bogs, preserving long chronological sequences. McDonald, a trained palynologist, will identify pollen types and frequency through high-powered microscopy, and samples will be dated through tephrochronology and AMS 14C dating of plant macrofossils. Resulting data enables reconstruction of climate, environmental conditions, and increases and decreases in plants associated with crop cultivation and pasturage at each settlement locale. 

In addition to information on the relationship between governments and taxpayers, the project will create a series of classroom lesson plans and YouTube videos aimed at elementary and middle school children, introducing archaeological methods and past cultures, enhancing competencies in science, social studies, math, and language arts.

por.por_cntn:
Erin McDonald has completed research for her dissertation “Long Term Interactions between Social Organization and Land Use Practices” supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant. During her funding period, McDonald spent four weeks working in the pollen lab at the School of Natural and Built Environment at Queen’s University Belfast (QUB) in Northern Ireland processing pollen samples from peat cores extracted from four bogs in the midlands of Ireland. Additionally, twenty macrobotanical samples were collected from strategic locations along the cores and were prepared for submission to the CHRONO lab at QUB for Accelerator Mass Spectrometry (AMS) dating. Preliminary analyses of the cores showed that no identifiable volcanic tephras were present, thus ending the plan to date the cores using tephrachronology.

 

At the University at Buffalo, McDonald spent six months identifying and counting more than 500 pollen grains per each of the 128 samples processed at QUB. Once the pollen counts were completed, the raw data were compiled into percentage diagrams. These diagrams showed the changes in vegetation over the course of the Late Bronze Age, Iron Age and Early Medieval Period of Ireland. Generally, the vegetation changes depicted in the pollen diagrams were the result of human activity in the landscape (e.g. woodland clearance for pasture or crop agriculture and woodland regeneration when land was abandoned). Of particular interest was identifying changes in land use over time as reflected in the pollen record, and associating those land use practices with changing organizational strategies of communities in Iron Age Ireland. Different farming practices reflect different ways of life. Sedentary farmers living in dense settlements will not necessarily have the same decision-making strategies as dispersed populations of nomadic pastoralists.

 

The pollen record and inferred farming practices help to put people in a landscape that is archaeologically sparse. The data collected during this project period will be interpreted through current, relevant archaeological theory regarding socio-political organization, contributing to a re-evaluation of previous notions about the Iron Age in Ireland. This project is an example of an interdisciplinary approach to the past, combining palaeoecological techniques, archaeological data, and recent archaeological theories that developed out of political science and sociology.

 

The research completed before and during the funding period forms the basis of McDonald’s dissertation. To be completed by September 2017, the dissertation is a contribution to furthering our understanding of Iron Age Ireland and an example of the effectiveness of interdisciplinary and inter-collegiate research. Once her dissertation is complete, McDonald will share her passion for archaeology, pollen, and Ireland with school children via the creation of a series of brief educational videos available to the public and recommended to teachers at local Buffalo schools
